Ivanova sat crosslegged on her bed in what could only be described as a quandary. Two jackets were laid out in front of her. One was the jacket of her military uniform, the rest of which was hanging, neatly pressed, in her closet. The other was the leather jacket Faith had given her Saturday night, in the same blue and brown. Upon closer inspection, even the command insignia along her collar were there. Captain. She'd barely even worn the title when this new life had swallowed her whole. No, the jackets weren't her quandary. She knew which one she was choosing at the moment. As soon as she was done with this she would hang the uniform jacket in the closet with the rest of it, for if and when she was needed on duty. It was the patch on the shoulder of her jacket that was causing her grief. The Babylon 5 insignia was, to her, the most important part of the uniform. It was where her closest allegiances lay, inextricably bound with her loyalty to Earth. And, as Faith had said, every biker needs to have colours. So, logically, the patch should be removed from the uniform and put on the leather jacket. She had needle and thread to do so. She even had the skill needed. But defacing her uniform was . . . hard. She was pretty sure it was against regulations (not that that really mattered to her, most of the time). But she also knew that replicating the patch was against regulations, and that one rather did matter to her, in a sort of twisted logic. Regulations are really more like guidelines anyway, right? Taking a deep breath, she jerked the patch free from the uniform and began sewing. [[Open for visitors!]]

Alright. I won't go over every detail of Ivanova's past, as you can find a very thorough and accurately reference biogrpahy here and a good character profile here. I quite like the opening line of that one: "A Russian Jew, who has lost all of her blood relatives to various tragedies, and has never done well in romances, Susan is an odd combination of perky, paranoid, hopeful and fatalistic." But there are a few points I'd like to stress, as well as where she stands in her personal canon. The matter of telepathy is a big one. First of all, Ivanova hates telepaths. In the glorious world of the future, it was decided on Earth that telepaths are dangerous. As such, they are all registered and strictly controlled by the PsiCorps. Usually people are identified as telepaths quite young, either by their parents turning them in, voluntarily turning themselves in, or periodic screening by schools. The children are then given to the PsiCorps to raise - one of the reasons that all telepaths have the slogan "The Corps is mother, the Corps is father permanently tattooed on their brains. If a person is identified as a telepath, they have three choices: join the Corps and leave their former life; go to jail; be put on a regime of telepathy-suppressing drugs. Ivanova's mother was a telepath who avoided detection until her thirty-fifth birthday, when Ivanova was eleven. She was put on the drugs, which eventually caused her to commit suicide after losing more and more of herself. Thus, the reason that Ivanova hates telepaths. The irony of the situation is that Ivanova herself is a low-level, latent telepath. Her family moved around a lot to keep one step ahead of the Corps, and her mother taught her how to fool the tests at school. She can't do very much at all except block another telepath from entering her mind. Here's where we break from canon a bit. The Fandomyness of Fandom High caused her abilities to develop slightly. She's still only a P1 at best, but she can read surface thoughts of people she is very, very close to. At the moment, this means Tonks and that's it. She's slightly empathetic, but her naturally abrasive personality renders this almost void. So, if your character is a telepath and Ivanova finds this out - whether by you saying something or attempting to scan her - she will be very, very angry. It's a gut reaction from a lifetime spent in fear that she'll probably get over fairly quickly, but she'll still be very suspicious of you. Which brings me to my second point. Lurve. Ivanova is snarky, sarcastic, and very, very skeptical. Partially because of her horrible track record in love. She has three romantic interests throughout the show: the guy whose name I can never remember, Talia Winters, and Marcus Cole. The first was a one-episode renewal of an old relationship, but the guy in question turned out to be an anti-alien, pro-human militant who was sent to jail for trying to kill an ambassador. The romance with Talia probably lasted about a season. They have breakfast together a few times, and only the most WASPy WASP could miss the fact that they were sleeping together in the episode 'Divided Loyalties'. Ivanova also admits to loving Talia a few episodes later; what makes this tragic is that she's a PsiCorps commerical telepath. Talia was secretly programmed as a spy by the PsiCops, the military arm of the PsiCorps, and her hidden program was activated. Her personality was wiped and replaced by a cold bitch who didn't care anything for Ivanova. Painful break-up number one. Number two was Marcus Cole. After the Talia incident, Ivanova got gunshy. She didn't let herself fall in love again because she was afraid of getting hurt. So for two seasons, she and Marcus just USTed all over the place while being ridiculously adorable. Then she got blown up and he saved her life. Using an alien device, he literally sapped his own life to give it to her. And because there was no one there to stop the process, he died. Painful break-up number two, complete with heart-breaking monologue about how all love is unrequited and she should have at least boffed him. And with love comes sex. Obviously. So let's talk about Ivanova's sexual orientation for a moment. She is canonically bisexual. This isn't me and slash fans like me reading into the material. The Great Maker himself declared it so, as did Claudia Christian in her infamous interview in which she said, "I've been typecast. I'm the Russian bisexual telepathic Jew." So, yes, she's Jewish, too. To make her a bit more random. She also said the following:
Claudia: Ivanova only spent one night with her lover, Talia. It was done in such a way that if you were a kid you could say, "oh it's a sleep-over!" and if you were and adult you might go "hmmm". And, of course, if you were a bloke you'd go "Whoa! Yeah!" FH1: Do you really think they had sex then? Claudia: Yeah, we were a little too old for sleep-overs. FH1: Are you glad you didn't have to do a screen kiss for the part? Claudia: I wouldn't have minded. Andrea Thompson [who plays Talia] is a beautiful woman, and we were er . . . friendly.
Anyways, this makes her one of the first (and only) bisexual characters on television, because she isn't straight-who-becomes-gay or gay-who-is-cured. She loved Talia, and had a thing with Marcus. Several previous relationships are hinted at, but the only one for certain was with a man. Now, I say 'had a thing' for a reason. She never, ever says that she loves Marcus. Marcus says it. His dying words are actually, "I love you." Ivanova only says that she should have boffed him at the very least. All of her subsequent romantic relationships in Fandom have been with women. Unless you count flirting with Han Solo and that one drunken one-night-stand with Blackadder. But! Onwards, to . . . . . . Fandom! My Ivanova is the same one that was at Fandom High. Her original reasons for leaving Babylon 5 are the same as in the show: she was running away from Marcus's death. In the show, she was promoted to captain and given a ship of her own for a shakedown cruise. For Fandom purposes, this wasn't quite fast or far enough, and Zathras brought her to Fandom. See my note on Zathras and the Great Machine here. She was recalled a few times during the year to deal with crises back on the station and after graduation returned with the intent of resuming her position as captain. See the explanation of what happened with that here. While at Fandom, Ivanova recovered enough from her hideous karmatic debt to fall in love with Tonks. After she left, Ivanova drank herself into a stupor for a week straight, had a regrettable one night stand with Blackadder, and sobered up. Comfort came in the form of Maia Rutledge, both of them missing Tonks, and an almost-fling with Pip Bernadette. And that's about it, really. A couple of small notes: Ivanova is thirty-one, but her body is physically around twenty-one. It's 2261 where she comes from.
